prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Disposition in the transferee court—Disposition on pretrial motions

para.paratext: Transferee courts have the clear power to consider all pretrial motions, including motions that are dispositive of claims or defenses or of the entire litigation. This power is consistent with the legislative history of the statute.[1]

The most common dispositive motions are motions to dismiss under Rule 12,[2] and motions for summary judgment under Rule 56.[3] Most often, these motions have been used in multidistrict litigation to dispose of certain issues or claims in the transferred cases, rather than the entire litigation. Both have been used by transferee courts to dispose of issues in cases transferred under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407.[4] Transferee courts have, however, disposed of entire cases upon motion.[5] The Panel has explicitly recognized the authority and power of the transferee court to dispose of a transferred case on motion prior to remand.[6]

Resolution of all common issues on summary judgment, but possibly not all the issues in all the transferred cases, may result in either a motion for remand or suggestion by the transferee judge to the Panel that remand is appropriate. Where the court grants summary judgment on all issues in some transferred cases, they become immediately appealable to the circuit having jurisdiction over appeals from the transferee court, while cases where other issues remain would not be appealable at that time. If they are then remanded by the Panel to the districts where they were filed, they would become appealable only when the proceedings on remand were complete, and then to the circuit court having jurisdiction over the court. An alternative for the transferee court would be to enter a partial final judgment pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b), in order to permit the entire summary judgment order to be reviewed in a single appeal by a single court (and to require that it be done at that time, if at all).[7] In one case involving summary judgment under complex issues of differing state laws, the court chose to remand the cases without making a Rule 54(b) certification, and the Panel remanded the remaining cases to the transferor courts.[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See In re Donald J. Trump Casino Securities Litigation-Taj Mahal Litigation, 7 F.3d 357, 364–68 (3d Cir. 1993), cert. denied, 510 U.S. 1178, 114 S. Ct. 1219, 127 L. Ed. 2d 565 (1994). The legislative history of 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 is discussed in § 2:3.

See Fed. R. Civ. P. 12. Motions to dismiss are discussed in greater detail in David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Motion Practice§§ 9.06 (failure to state a claim), 10.01 (lack of subject-matter jurisdiction), 10.02 (lack of personal jurisdiction) and 11.03 (improper venue) (8th ed. 2018).
See Fed. R. Civ. P. 56. Motions for summary judgment are discussed in greater detail in David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel Motion Practice§ 16.1 (8th ed. 2019).

See, e.g., Hammer v. Clear Channel Communications, Inc. (In re Live Concert Antiturst Litigation), 863 F. Supp. 2d 966 (C.D. Cal. 2012) (motion excluding expert witnesses and granting summary judgment on antitrust claims); In re TMJ Implants Products Liability Litigation, 872 F. Supp. 1019 (D. Minn. 1995), judgment aff'd, 97 F.3d 1050 (8th Cir. 1996) (partial summary judgment granted to fewer than all defendants); In re KMF Actions, 56 F.R.D. 128 (D. Mass. 1972), judgment aff'd, 479 F.2d 257 (1st Cir. 1973), cert. denied, 414 U.S. 857, 94 S. Ct. 161, 38 L. Ed. 2d 107 (1973) (damage claim dismissed, motion to dismiss claim for injunction denied); In re Puerto Rico Air Disaster Litigation, 340 F. Supp. 492 (D.P.R. 1972) (dismissal of certain cases for lack of jurisdiction); Jack Winter, Inc. v. Koratron Co., 329 F. Supp. 211 (N.D. Cal. 1971) (summary judgment ordered on third-party complaint), 327 F. Supp. 206 (summary judgment denied on patent validity); In re Motor Vehicle Air Pollution Control Equipment, 52 F.R.D. 398 (C.D. Cal. 1970) (class certified but constitutional claims dismissed).
See, e.g., In re Alsco-Harvard Fraud Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 315, 316 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
See Haddad v. Crosby Corp., 374 F. Supp. 95 (D.D.C. 1973) (civil and criminal antitrust actions dismissed).

The foregoing language was quoted by the United Supreme Court in Gelboim v. Bank of America Corp., 134 S. Ct. 2876, 189 L. Ed. 2d 832 (2014), which decided that an order deciding all the issues in a particular case in an MDL proceeding is appealable, even though other issues remain in other cases. This decision is also discussed in § 11:5, below.

See FedEx Ground Package System, Inc. v. United States Panel on Multidistrict Litigation, 662 F.3d 887 (7th Cir. 2011) (denying mandamus review of Panel remand decision). The Seventh Circuit decision reviews the Panel's decision remanding upon recommendation of the transferee judge, following entry of summary judgments on some, but not all, claims, see In re Fedex Ground Package System, Inc., 734 F. Supp. 2d 557 (N. D. Ind. 2010) (deciding choice of law issues as to Kansas plaintiffs) and 758 F. Supp. 2d (N. D. Ind. 2010) (deciding issues as to balance of transferor jurisdictions).
